50 to 60 years ago,

Venezuela had one of the
most prosperous economies

in the world because of its
newly discovered oil reserves.
The Venezuelan Boulevard was very strong

and Venezuelan workers
enjoyed the highest wages
in all of Latin America,

but in the end it was
all too good to be true.

The dream life faded away
when oil prices collapsed

and a fractured political
system couldn't agree

on any policies nor make
any of the right decisions.

Then on June 2nd, 2010,
former president Hugo Chavez
declared an economic war

due to increasing food
shortages in Venezuela.
Since then, over the last 11 years,

the problem has gotten
significantly worse.
Today Venezuela faces extreme cases

of hyperinflation, starvation,
disease, and crime,
resulting in the massive immigration of

over 5 million who now
call themselves refugees.

According to economists
interviewed by the New York times,
Venezuela's economic crisis is more severe

than any country in
the last hundred years.
Far worse than the US Great Depression

and the 2008, 2009
hyperinflation of Zimbabwe.

The official currency of
Venezuela is called bolivares,
named after its former president
who led them to independence.

to 1.4 million bolivares,
but now as I speak this,

is less than $1 US dollar a month.
